was it was critical to have a really technically strong product so in our
case this meant really strict infrastructure as code practices where all of our configuration for our
underlying infrastructure is captured as configuration files and these configuration files are very strictly
version controlled and our Version Control System you know requires two of our team members from a very specific
team to you know one makes the P request and one's more just the poll request
right you know this this is a relatively ordinary practice but we framed it as strict configuration
management because that's what it really is we also have a very strict practice
of continuous deployment we never have human hands messing around in production all of our changes go through
configuration management continuous deployment that really helped with like
a surprisingly huge number of controls um and on the documentation
side which is really the side that I was working on as a technical writer we learned through experience that it was
critical to have your technical writer your content designer as we call it at
atnf embedded within your technical team you know I know my technical team
they're my teammates you know I know that their children are adorable and that they're wonderful people and so we
worked both one-on-one together where you know the platform engineer who had implemented this platform and I you know
talked it through looked at the requirement you know asked one of our teammates who was really good at sort of
understanding compliance language for more advice device on interpreting the control and we wrote it together we also
had our Engineers pair together on writing the documentation and this is a
very common practice in mature engineering teams to do pair programming
but we learned that pair documentation writing is also critical because you got to talk it through when you're trying to
explain something and really the PTO documentation is fundamentally about explaining your system in our case to
the Joint authorization board we learned learned also through experience through a series of mistakes that it was
critical to keep our diagrams as code in Version Control as well because the
documentation package requires very detailed and complex diagrams that the
joint authorization board reviewers uses almost like a glossery as they evaluate
the system so we used a simple open- Source markup language and maintained
our diagrams in that markup language which then automatically generate our diagrams so you're never asking like
who's got the latest file you know it's right there and for example I'm a
technical writer I understand how to explain things I don't always understand the platform details precisely I could
make a PO request you know make a proposal for how to clarify the diagram and one of our Engineers could review my
change and merge it after they verified that it was technically correct as
well we also ended up needing to keep our team policies and procedures in our Version Control so that our Engineers
were familiar with also how to make changes this makes sure that our policies and procedures are in line with
our actual practices because everyone on our team knows how to propose a change
and get that change reviewed and that you know we can always roll it back we
can work on different branches so much easier than maintaining a series of word docs so much easier can't explain how
much easier it is um and then on the compliance side we made sure to leverage
as much as we possibly could from underlying systems so we leveraged the
